abstract.p: Barry Edelson letter responds to Oct 25 front-page article on dissension at Carnegie Hall; hopes article will shed light on routine mistreatment of employees in the arts community (M)

block.p: Your Oct. 25 front-page article about dissension at Carnegie Hall was astonishing, not because management crises are rare in venerated cultural institutions, but because the devastating effect on staff members is almost never mentioned in public.

Your Oct. 25 front-page article about dissension at Carnegie Hall was astonishing, not because management crises are rare in venerated cultural institutions, but because the devastating effect on staff members is almost never mentioned in public.

As one who has worked in public relations at two symphony orchestras, I know it is all too common for employees in the not-for-profit arena to be subjected to unchecked harassment by executives who justify their abuses by claiming to serve the higher causes of art and philanthropy.

Thousands of young people flock to New York from around the country to work in an arts community that they, like the public in general, naively imagine to be a genteel and humane environment. Perhaps a bit of chaos at Carnegie Hall will help shed some light on the routine mistreatment of so many who labor in an industry that is so important to the city.
